@graph.parties: Verizon Communications Inc. v. Law Offices of Curtis V. Trinko, LLP
@graph.reasoning: Verizon's alleged insufficient assistance in the provision of service to rivals is not a recognized antitrust claim under this Court's existing refusal-to-deal precedents.

@graph.parties: Aspen Skiing Co. v. Aspen Highlands Skiing Corp.
@graph.reasoning: What the defendant refused to provide to its competitor was a product that it already sold at retail.

@graph.parties: Otter Tail Power Co. v. United States
@graph.reasoning: The defendant was already in the business of providing a service to certain customers and refused to provide the same service to certain other customers.
The 1996 Act's extensive provision for access makes it unnecessary to impose a judicial doctrine of forced access.

@graph.parties: United States v. Terminal Railroad Assn. of St. Louis
@graph.reasoning: This case involved concerted action, which presents greater anticompetitive concerns and is amenable to a remedy that does not require judicial estimation of free-market forces.
This case involved concerted action, which presents greater anticompetitive concerns and is amenable to a remedy that does not require judicial estimation of free-market forces.

@graph.parties: United States v. Citizens & Southern Nat. Bank
@graph.reasoning: Careful account must be taken of the pervasive federal and state regulation characteristic of the industry.

@graph.parties: Silver v. New York Stock Exchange
@graph.reasoning: Where there is nothing built into the regulatory scheme which performs the antitrust function, the benefits of antitrust are worth its sometimes considerable disadvantages.
Antitrust analysis must sensitively recognize and reflect the distinctive economic and legal setting of the regulated industry to which it applies.

@graph.parties: United States v. National Assn. of Securities Dealers, Inc.
@graph.reasoning: Where such a structure exists, the additional benefit to competition provided by antitrust enforcement will tend to be small, and it will be less plausible that the antitrust laws contemplate such additional scrutiny.
